author: Michaela Whitbourn
title: Former TZ boss Andrew Sigalla jailed for up to 10 years for $9 million fraud
text:
Tom Waterhouse arrives to give evidence at the Andrew Sigalla trial in October last year. Photo: Nick Moir 
Justice Adamson said Sigalla was akin to a "gamekeeper who poaches" and "helped himself" to $8.6 million from TZ when it suited him. 
He displayed an "indignant" and "intransigent" attitude during the criminal investigation and went to "extraordinary lengths" to conceal his wrongdoing, she said. 
The entire board of TZ was replaced in June 2009. Sigalla was holidaying in the Bahamas two months later when lawyers for the new board wrote to him seeking an explanation for certain payments. 
Bookmaker Tom Waterhouse gave evidence during the trial that Sigalla was a "big punter" who was "known by all the bookmakers" at the race track. 
Justice Adamson said Sigalla enjoyed a relatively "privileged" upbringing and had attended Sydney Grammar School until his Higher School Certificate. 
He then studied economics and law at the University of Sydney but the court heard his life was also marred by tragedy. 
Sigalla's legal studies were cut short when his much younger sister died and he was required to run the family business. 
Sigalla's father died of a heart attack a year later and the family solicitor committed suicide after defrauding a number of clients, including the Sigalla family. 
But Justice Adamson said no other sentence but a term of imprisonment was appropriate in the case in light of the seriousness of the charges. 
His lawyer had conceded that his client did not believe he had done anything wrong. 
Sigalla will be eligible for parole in November 2022. Related Content
